review_title: A Good Bank to work with
pros: I don't see any pros
cons: Employee friendly Bank or company you can say.

pros:
Salary, benefits, and hours are excellent for the Jacksonville area. PTO is generous.

DB is going through a transformation that is being reflected in the Jacknsoillve office. Although there have been layoffs of higher ranking individuals, DB continues to hire and promote its young talent. 

The Jacksonville office is a combination of back, middle, and front office. There is truly every type of seniority and role here.
cons:
DB is falling behind in plenty of areas. Technology is simply abysmal, they cannot remain competitive if they continue to rely on outdated infrastructure to run their business.

Work here is pretty mundane - do not expect to learn the latest technological skills in the industry.

Culture depends on the team that you are on, management likes to play favorites. More politics than the roman high court.

job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- Junior employees are mostly friendly and competent
- Better work/life balance than most boutiques
- Good health insurance
cons:
- Deutsche Bank has serious cultural issues in some teams. There are many terrible mid-level managers who are simply toxic people while the bank kept them, simply because they could not find a job anywhere else

- Investment Banking division's reputation has been tainted by past legal woes and bad press associated with Trump. All those led to diminishing deal flow, low employee morale, and excessive office politics. Everyone I know is looking for a job somewhere else

- As a former LGBT employee, I don’t believe this bank actually cares about its people or diversity & inclusion, but they care more about how they look publicly. When (frequent) restructuring happens, you will be the first target

I do not recommend any young people starting their career or any LGBT employee who wants to be respected join the company. It’s not a decent place to pursue a career. It's a sinking ship and you better run.

review_title: Exciting and Challenging Work Place With Some Downsides
job_title: Global Service Delivery Manager in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Exciting and challenging environment with a lot of opportunities to be involved in additional projects or work streams.
There is a strong culture of encouraging people to be innovative and to take ownership for those innovations.
There are a large number of inspiring, smart and hardworking people who are a pleasure to work with.
Very good opportunities for training, self development, coaching and mentoring.
cons:
Constant reorganisation within the company which rarely bring any actual improvements.
Very hub centric (London, New York etc) with opportunities and benefits much reduced in other locations of the same country.
Archaic and complicated processes exist across the board.
The promotion process happens once a year and it can be very difficult to get promoted regardless of how well a person has performed. People can be pigeon holed into a role where visibility and opportunity are not available and they are then overlooked
There is an expectation of long and unsocial hours with little acknowledgement or reward.

cons:
- Most are arrogant who still hold on their arrogance from the glory days of when DB was a top bank
- People are often arrogant and rude
- You will rarely work on the best deals as competition is tough and it’s not easy to beat the US banks

- A lot of stress on juniors given barely staffed team structures

review_title: Working For DB Is Like Working For A Gentle Giant. Here's why.
pros:
- Solid benefits, health insurance options are diverse with great premiums, 401(k).
- European style paid time off 
- You never know when and how frequent your body decides to punish you. Unlimited sick leave.
- Flexible work/life balance
- HR is very available and helpful.
- Constant improvements to keep up to date with the latest tech stacks
- Diversity, has a strong LGBTQ community.
- No more command & control. Mutual cooperation.
- Great exposure to various tech stacks. 
- Expert level developers in each team. I came in with 1 year of experience, experienced enough to avoid any straight out of college training, but not experienced enough to be thrown to the wolves. The wolves were actually sheep and I learned a valuable and great deal from them.
cons: - You have to "play the game" at some point and to some degree.
